purpose.summary: This policy establishes a standardized framework for setting, managing, and adjusting sales quotas across Henry Schein. The policy ensures quotas are fair, achievable, aligned with business objectives, and consistently applied while providing appropriate governance over mid-year adjustments.
objectives: Establish standardized framework for setting sales quotas
Ensure quotas are fair, achievable, and aligned with business objectives
Provide governance framework for mid-year quota adjustments
Maintain consistency in quota administration across the organization

appliesTo: All sales roles with defined quota targets
All divisions and business units within Henry Schein
Annual quota setting and mid-year quota adjustments

definitions.definition: The sales target assigned to an individual, team, or territory representing expected performance over a defined period.
The initial quota assigned at the beginning of the performance period based on historical performance, territory potential, and business objectives.
A quota that has been modified during the performance period due to qualifying circumstances as defined in this policy.
The percentage of quota achieved, calculated as actual results divided by assigned quota.
The estimated total addressable market or revenue opportunity within a defined sales territory.
A reduction in quota due to circumstances outside the sales representative's control.
The theoretical maximum sales that can be achieved given available resources and market conditions.

provisions.title: Quota Setting Principles and Methodology
provisions.content: Henry Schein's quota setting process is guided by core principles and a balanced methodology.

subProvisions.title: Core Principles
subProvisions.content: Quota setting follows these guiding principles:
items: Alignment: Quotas align with corporate financial goals and strategic objectives
Fairness: Similar roles in similar territories receive comparable quota treatment
Achievability: Quotas are challenging yet attainable with strong performance
Transparency: Methodology and factors are clearly communicated
Consistency: Similar situations are treated consistently across the organization
Data-Driven: Quotas are based on objective data and analysis

subProvisions.title: Quota Setting Methodology
subProvisions.content: Quotas are established using a balanced approach with weighted factors:
items: Historical Performance (40% weight): Prior 3-year average sales performance, year-over-year growth trends, seasonality patterns
Territory Potential (30% weight): Market size and penetration analysis, customer base size and growth potential, competitive landscape, geographic and demographic factors
Strategic Priorities (20% weight): Corporate growth targets, product/service mix objectives, new market penetration goals, strategic account development
Resource Allocation (10% weight): Territory size and account count, support staff availability, marketing and lead generation support

subProvisions.title: Target Attainment Expectations
subProvisions.content: Quotas are set with the following attainment distribution:
items: 50-60% of team: Expected to achieve 90-110% of quota (on-target performance)
20-25% of team: Expected to exceed 110% of quota (high performers)
15-25% of team: May achieve 70-90% of quota (developing or challenging territories)
Overall team attainment target: 95-105% of aggregate quota

provisions.title: Annual Quota Setting Process
provisions.content: Structured process and timeline for annual quota setting with defined approval requirements.

subProvisions.title: Timeline
subProvisions.content: The annual quota setting process follows a structured timeline from September through January.

subProvisions.title: Approval Requirements
subProvisions.content: Annual quotas require hierarchical approvals:
items: Territory/Individual Quotas: Regional Sales Manager
Regional Aggregated Quotas: Divisional VP of Sales
Divisional Quotas: SVP of Sales + CFO
Corporate Consolidated Quotas: CEO + Board of Directors

tables.caption: Annual Quota Setting Timeline
rows: Finance provides corporate revenue targets to divisions
Divisional leadership allocates targets to territories
Sales Compensation develops preliminary quota recommendations
Review with Sales Leadership and Finance
Quotas effective for new fiscal year

provisions.title: Mid-Year Quota Adjustments
provisions.content: Mid-year quota adjustments are discouraged and require strong justification. This provision establishes clear triggers and approval thresholds.

subProvisions.title: Qualifying Triggers for Quota Adjustment
subProvisions.content: Quota adjustments may be approved only for the following circumstances:
items: Territory Changes: Significant addition or removal of accounts (>20% of territory), geographic territory expansion or contraction, territory splits or mergers

Market Conditions: Major customer bankruptcy or business closure (>$1M impact), regulatory changes affecting product availability, natural disaster or force majeure events, significant competitive displacement (documented loss of >15% territory value)

Internal Changes: Role change with different responsibilities, significant product line additions or discontinuations, corporate restructuring or acquisitions, extended leave of absence (>60 consecutive days)
Performance Period Changes: New hire starting mid-year (proration), promotion or transfer (quota transition)

subProvisions.title: Non-Qualifying Reasons
subProvisions.content: Quota adjustments will NOT be approved for:
items: Below-target performance or difficulty achieving quota
General market softness affecting all territories equally
Temporary sales slowdowns (<2 consecutive quarters)
Personal circumstances unrelated to territory potential
Desire to increase earnings potential

subProvisions.title: Timing of Adjustments
subProvisions.content: Quota adjustments must meet timing requirements:
items: Requested within 30 days of the triggering event
Effective prospectively from the date of approval (no retroactive adjustments)
Limited to once per quarter per individual (except for role changes)
Finalized by the 15th of the month to take effect that same month

tables.caption: Adjustment Thresholds and Approval Levels
rows: Regional Sales Manager + Sales Comp Director
VP of Sales + VP Sales Compensation + Finance
SVP Sales + CFO + Comp Review Board

provisions.title: Territory Changes and Quota Impact
provisions.content: Specific rules for quota adjustments when territories change.

subProvisions.title: Territory Addition Quota Treatment
subProvisions.content: When accounts or geography are added to a territory:
items: Quota increases proportionally based on historical performance of added accounts
90-day ramp period applied for new account familiarization
Minimum addition threshold: Accounts representing >5% of current quota

subProvisions.title: Territory Reduction Quota Treatment
subProvisions.content: When accounts or geography are removed from a territory:
items: Quota decreases based on trailing 12-month performance of removed accounts
Adjustment is effective immediately upon account transfer
In-flight opportunities may be retained if >50% sales cycle complete

subProvisions.title: Territory Split Methodology
subProvisions.content: When a territory is divided between multiple representatives:
items: Total quota for split territories equals 100-105% of original quota
Each new territory receives quota based on account distribution and historical performance
5% increase accounts for additional coverage and focus

provisions.title: New Business vs. Renewal/Retention Quotas
provisions.content: Different quota types based on role responsibilities.

subProvisions.title: Hunter Roles (New Business Focus)
subProvisions.content: New customer acquisition focused roles:
items: 80-100% of quota from new customer acquisition
Quota based on average deal size × expected close rate × number of opportunities
Sales cycle length factored into quota calculations

subProvisions.title: Farmer Roles (Account Management Focus)
subProvisions.content: Existing customer management roles:
items: 70-90% of quota from existing customer base
Quota based on retention rate × growth targets
Churn risk factored into quota setting

subProvisions.title: Hybrid Roles
subProvisions.content: Mixed responsibility roles:
items: Split quotas: e.g., 60% retention + 40% new business
Each component tracked and measured separately
Separate attainment calculations for each quota component

provisions.title: Documentation Requirements
provisions.content: Comprehensive documentation requirements for quota assignments and changes.

subProvisions.title: Quota Assignment Documentation
subProvisions.content: Each quota assignment must include:
items: Individual or territory identifier
Quota amount(s) by measure (revenue, GP, units, etc.)
Performance period
Account/territory scope
Commission plan reference
Approval signatures and dates

subProvisions.title: Quota Adjustment Request Form
subProvisions.content: All adjustment requests must include:
items: Current quota and proposed new quota
Percentage change
Triggering event with dates and specifics
Impact analysis (financial and performance)
Supporting documentation (territory changes, market data, etc.)
Year-to-date performance context
Recommendation from direct manager

subProvisions.title: Quota Change Log
subProvisions.content: Sales Compensation maintains a comprehensive quota change log capturing all adjustments with required fields.
items: Employee name and ID
Original quota
Adjusted quota
Change reason and category
Approval chain
Effective date
Supporting documentation reference

provisions.title: Fairness Review and Appeals Process
provisions.content: Process for ensuring fair quota assignments and handling appeals.

subProvisions.title: Quota Fairness Review
subProvisions.content: Prior to finalizing annual quotas, Sales Compensation conducts a fairness analysis:
items: Quota per account comparisons across similar territories
Quota growth rate analysis (ensure consistency)
Territory potential vs. quota alignment checks
Outlier identification and justification

subProvisions.title: Quota Appeal Process
subProvisions.content: Sales representatives may appeal their annual quota assignment through a three-step process:
items: Step 1: Initial Review with Manager - Rep discusses concerns with direct manager within 15 days of quota notification
Step 2: Formal Appeal - If unsatisfied, rep submits written appeal to Sales Compensation within 30 days with specific data-driven rationale
Step 3: Final Review - Unresolved appeals escalate to Quota Review Committee whose decision is final

provisions.title: Roles and Responsibilities
provisions.content: Clearly defined roles for all parties involved in quota management.

subProvisions.title: Finance Department
subProvisions.content: Financial planning and oversight:
items: Provide corporate revenue and profitability targets
Validate quota allocations align with financial plan
Approve divisional quota distributions
Monitor quota attainment vs. financial targets

subProvisions.title: Sales Leadership
subProvisions.content: Sales management responsibilities:
items: Translate financial targets into territory quotas
Assess territory potential and resource allocation
Review and approve regional quota distributions
Advocate for fair and achievable quota assignments

subProvisions.title: Sales Compensation Team
subProvisions.content: Administration and governance:
items: Develop quota methodology and recommendations
Conduct fairness analysis across territories
Process adjustment requests and maintain documentation
Administer quota appeal process
Maintain quota change log and audit trail

subProvisions.title: Regional Sales Managers
subProvisions.content: Front-line quota management:
items: Review and approve territory-level quotas
Submit quota adjustment requests with justification
Communicate quotas to sales teams
Support reps through appeals process when appropriate

subProvisions.title: Compensation Review Board
subProvisions.content: Executive oversight:
items: Review and approve quotas requiring executive oversight
Evaluate large quota adjustments (>25%)
Serve as final appeal authority
Ensure consistency with governance policies
